citeinfo.title: NMHU Valles Caldera and Jemez Springs Las Conchas Macroinvertebrates, 2011 - 2012

descript.abstract: The Valles Caldera, located in Northern New Mexico is being affected by climate change. The most pronounced effects on the region are the increasing temperatures and decreasing snowpack. Climate change is expected to increase wildfire severity. Following large wildfires, the potential for soil erosion during precipitation events is also increased, therefore potentially degrading the aquatic system. The purpose of this study is to determine the impact of the Las Conchas wildfire had on diversity and populations of aquatic macro invertebrates. Samples were collected from various parts of the steam pre and post fire. The macro invertebrates will be sorted, counted, and identified to family. This is preformed to determine the effects of large wildfire on the aquatic macro invertebrate ecosystem. Future research will be conducted to determine the length of time needed for aquatic macro invertebrates to increase in numbers.
descript.purpose: This study was conducted in the Valles Caldera, in northern New Mexico by the water quality group at NMHU under New Mexico EPSCoR.

overview.eaover: Invertebrates were collected at the Valles Caldera National Preserve and surrounding Jemez Mountains, during the summer of 2011 (June), fall of 2011 (October), spring of 2012 (April), and summer of 2012 (June). Invertebrate collection at each site was divided into three sections, a collection at and/or right below the spring, a collection at above the confluence of the spring and river, and a collection below the confluence below the spring and river. Collection at each site spanned approximately 20 meters of the river, and quantitative sample were collected. In the lab invertebrates were identified into taxonomic family, as well as into functional feeding guilds (shredder, filtering collector, gathering collector, scrapper, and predators).
